reviewText:
Tl;dr: It's a decent hack 'n' slash game with good artwork, can get repetitive, made primarily for mobile devices, DON'T BUY IT ON STEAM SINCE IT'S FREE ON DESURA. Read below for more info.

I bought this game months ago (during a sale, phew!), and at first I remember I loved it. I loved the artwork, I loved the hack 'n' slash. I simply found this through browsing Steam, not their Kickstarter. I used to love just hacking and slashing, one downside was that to get better loots you have to do the same missions a few times with higher difficulty, just like other games, but this one doesn't make the higher difficulty more fun, it's rather boring to do it again and again in fact. (Which it still is now.)

As of writing this on November 11, 2014, yes, this game is free on Desura. Yes, there is micro-transaction, which is because this game was supposed to come out on iOS and Android as well. However, reading the comment section of their Kickstarter, there isn't any news on the phone versions yet. The weird controls are a result of this game being primarily a mobile game. You only use mouse left and right clicks which can be extremely irritating if you normally use WASD to move around.

The developing team is literally 1 person alone, and he had 2.7k people back the game with a total amount of 200k USD. Despite that, I didn't have high hopes after downloading it again today. In August, 2014, in which he replied comments on Akaneiro's Kickstarter, the developer explained the slow progress was due to him being alone in the whole development, HOWEVER, after the Kickstarter success in February 2013, he had since 1 failed and 1 successful Kickstarter campaign, both on different projects, with the latest successful one in August, 2013. So is he slacking off on developing this game?

I was fine with just going along and playing the game like I used to. However, I couldn't even load the one mission I wanted to play... I'm sorry but for now, I cannot recommend this game, especially since it's made for mobile WITHOUT controls for PC players, and its horrible development.
voteText: 72 of 83 people (87%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: Everyone has that one game". The game they regret buying or preordering. Some people have more than one. This game is "that one game" for many people. Spicy Horse has essentially abandoned the development of this game (they posted that the development team has been reduced to 2 members)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Akaneiro is a potentially cool Diablo clone ruined by a greedy free-to-play pay scheme. Yes, it's f2p- except on Steam, where you spend $10 on in-game currency to play it. $10 should buy you the whole game, and even then it's so simplistic it would be hard to recommend. And it still isn't feature complete, despite a $200,000 Kickstarter and charging microtransactions on an unfinished game. Totally unbalanced, too.

I'm not even sure what the state of the game is, either. It's still listed as early access" but I don't even know that it's being worked on any more. From what I can tell Spicy Horse has moved on to other projects on Kickstarter
date: leaving Akaneiro a half-finished mess. Having loved their work on Alice: Madness Returns
recommended: I'm disappointed by this game and their questionable business ethics."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI loved this game to bits in the beginning! Was looking forward to the promised co-op option. Sadly didn't happen. Was cool to have the option to summon a random character to help you out a bit, at least. I was shocked this game brought little to no profit to the developers. After the big changes that were made to the game, like changing the control keys (they used to be very well thought out, now they're confusing to use), I don't mind if a game is difficult, but the character is suddenly extremely weak physicaly and I have to heal every few seconds and constantly runaway from even one monster to avoid getting killed.. aaand ofc microtransactions.. I don't mind it as long as it's actually worth it, but here, it's not. Looked through everything and even though I was open to buy some of the karma crystals and/or shards, there's actually nothing really worth spending money on. Shame.. It used to be such an awesome and fun game in the beginning. *sad face* :(

Early Access Review

Wow, usually I'm smarter than this. This is paying for a F2P game. With microtransactions. If you buy this, you're just an idiot like me. Don't be an idiot.

As a free to play game, it's pretty bad. F2P usually means MMO. In this case it means barely functional. The UI is terrible and hard to figure out. The camera isn't controlled, so melee tank classes are highly favorable. Levelling up is a mystery (does it do anything?). Coming from having played many ARPGs, this one is definitely different. And not really in a good way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I first wrote a review of this game on 09/01/2014 13:48 GMT, now I feel I have to change it slightly.

Second review based on playing the early access version 06/05/2014 18:44 GMT

Still in Early Access, hardly anything has changed, bug fixes etc but no game changing mechanics no improvements on current mechanics and no massive new content. I regret buying this product, and I've seen them adveritising and kickstarting other games. I don't think they care for this game anymore, now that I've heard they lost like $2m of what they put into the game when the kickstarter campaign was only asking for $200,000. I sense a little corruption here and I'd stay SO FAR away from this game before you think about buying it. Try it when it has come out of early access, when it does become an actual free to play game. Or alternatively, I think there is a legit browser-based version of this (same content) that you can play FOR FREE.

- - - -
Parts of my original review, some edited.

I also disapprove making this game free to play and having it ridden with in-game stores, in-game currencies, bypassing gameplay and easy leveling/gear acquiring. I will be really disappointed if they stick to this because in my opinion it's very corrupt, and I'd rather pay full price than to have store updates, store discounts, and other cash-related ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shoved in my face. This game has a lot of potential if they would just leave this out of the game. It reminds me a little of The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot, and the in-game currency system pretty much ruined the 'fun' and 'drive' for me.

The only issue I've had with the game is that, once you get the starter pack, you need to claim your items from the in-game mail system in the village ON YOUR FIRST EVER CHARACTER and put your items in your stash if you ever decide to delete the FIRST CHARACTER. Making a character, then deciding you want to delete it BEFORE acquiring the exclusive items, will delete them. I know this from experience, and I'm now awaiting a reply from Spicy Horse support regarding this awful situation. I'm sure it will be resolved, however I don't think I could recommend this game with out warning others first.

*****NEW EDIT************* It never got resolved, and my hope was diminished. I actually messaged them and a few weeks later after the incident - they finally got back to me and said that they couldn't give me the shards, they could only give me the items, like the food, Steam necklace, etc, BECAUSE since I bought the game and had the problem and WAITED for a reply from their support, their Early Access starter pack changed it's meaning - but they still advertised it on their store page. I was extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at this. They couldn't give me the red or blue shards (these are used to purchase things, and blue shards are extremely hard to come by, unless you pay for them for in-game currency) so, I basically bought a FREE TO PLAY game, because I don't use EXP boosting food, or any ♥♥♥♥ like that. I bought a free to play game!!! For £6.99! Outrageous.
- - - -

Hugely disappointed in Spicy Horse, I loved the hour or so I had on Alice Madness Returns (double check your origin version of the game, there are bugs, I hit a massive glitch and I can't get any further now with out rebuying the game on Steam cos I'm guessing you keep that up to date) and I had high hopes for this game. I even made a video about it and expressed why the micro transactions and the whole free to play state of mind will crush any chances of this game being good. I was right. I can't recommend.

Hugely disappointed. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off I paid money for it, and I refuse to stick up for it just because I did. Spicy Horse get your act together please!!!!

reviewText:
I like this game a lot, the problem is that it keeps crashing and sometimes it takes my computer with it.

The controls are easy enough, hold the left mouse button and move the cursor to walk and click left to interact.  There's a few keys with menu's or special attack mapped to them.  Also, the game basically plays itself if you don't turn off the auto-attack option in the menu.

The art is interesting, the music is nice, there's an interesting story and world to explore.  I want to recommend it, but with three crashes and one that shut down my computer, i can't.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had high hopes for this game, and have been following it for a while. I last played in the beta, but here were still numerous problems with it, the most frustrating being the PS1-like loading screens. Decided to give it another try, but loading screens are still EXCRUTIATINGLY long for a game with very limited gameplay and cartooney graphics. In addition, there are still numerous bugs that need to be sorted out, and enemies often get stuck on the edge of the map where you cannot attack them. I may dabble in this game every now and then but would not recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to like this, I really did. Another Diablo clone. Which generally means great fun, or boring grind. Unfortunately, this is more of the later. It has plenty of style and personality to set it apart from it's peers, but that's pretty much all it has going for it. The entire system feels unpolished and unrealized. And there is a strange time based restriction system on replaying quests, like a few facebook games I've experienced.
I tried to like it, I really did. I feel bad for it, but it's just not any good.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So much wasted potential.

Back when it was first released [before it even got on steam,] the game was actually really good. Loading times were fast, fps was smooth, and there weren't random lag bursts or high memory usage/leaks.

Now it has more content, but is completely ridden with bugs and overall clunkyness.

I believe, unfortunately, that any revival attempt will be a wasted effort. It was a really nice game, and could be so much more, but money is an issue for the developers, and the players arent willing to supply that with what they have now.

The best hope for this game to actually become playable like it used to be is either the developers making it open-source and letting it go, or selling it dirt cheap to some other company that's willing to work on it.

In short, RIP Akaneiro, you could have been so much more.

reviewText:
The game requires you to be online in order to play, there's even a chat option too but multiplayer is nowhere to be seen (even in the store page states it's a single player game, which makes no sense to be always online).

The game is free to play but be aware the more you play the more unstable it gets, the amounts of lag make it unplayable (4990 of ping? seriously?) .

The art is pretty, the music is good, the gameplay is nothing special, with lots of bugs the worse of them is when your character can't level up for no apparent reason, so you keep playing expecting to level up at some point, enemy meshes overlap each other A LOT, it could've been better if it wasn't due to the online always feature, at leas it could've been bearable.

reviewText:
The gameplay is very repetitive and average hack 'n' slay stuff.

It can be fun for a while.
I like the japanese environment, the artwork, the kinds of armor, weapons and enemies.

But I can see why there are so many negative reviews: Because people bought it and regret it. I read in a lot of reviews that they expected something different...
I played it for free and to be honest I would've also regret it if I bought it. It's just not worth any money. When it's about a hack 'n' slay game, then there are many better to find.

As it is free to play now, you can give it a try and enjoy it for some time. But you probably won't invest much time in it, as it could be better.

Akaneiro definitely has potential, but it seems it won't be used. That's why in the end I write a negative review as well.

reviewText:
Here are the problems with the game as I see them:

1. Constant screen and sound stuttering.
2. Quality of Life improvements aren't even an afterthought - they don't exist. For example, you can't ctrl + click or Shift + Click to get items to and from your stash. The vendor where you buy items, you can't sell there. - How counter intuitive is that? It does have this nice feature where you can just sell anything from your inventory - ok, neat, but again counter intuitive. You can't use your mouse scroll wheel to scroll the item boxes at any vendors.
3. This game lacks polish all over. Tooltips aren't helpful. The buff bar only gives you icons, if you hover your mouse over them, nothing indicates what that icon is doing. The auto attack" feature in the game interferes with your ability to use skills. The UI is also clunky and the games does little to explain it to you
date: so this is why it feels clunky.\n4. Where is the lore
hoursPlayed: plot? Anything that I could use that might give me a reason to be engaged is missing almost entirely.\n\nThe only nice thing I will say about the game is that I like the art direction. I like the eastern theme. I do not recommend anyone throwing money at this game until they fix some of these issues."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun.  No doubt its an odd little game, but the time I have played it has been really enjoyable.  I go back to it from time to time and still enjoy it...for an hour or so at a time.  Its a fun little grinding game if you enjoy that kind of thing you should enjoy this.  I think my favorite thing about this game though is the look and feel of it.  Its very...artsy...or stylized if you will.  I like supporting these smaller games, especially when they look this...different from everything else out there right now.

I feel that it has enough good and interesting elements to recomend it for the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly I don't remember buying this game but hopefully I didn't pay a full $10 for it. I suspect I made this purchase sometime in 2013 in what could only be described as a period in my life that was filled by a blurred binge of two bags of grass, seventy-five pellets of mescaline, five sheets of high-powered blotter acid, a saltshaker half-full of cocaine, and a whole galaxy of multi-colored uppers, downers, screamers, laughers... Also, a quart of tequila, a quart of rum, a case of beer, a pint of raw ether, and two dozen amyls... But I am getting off point, the point was that this game was SO forgettable that the developers themselves forgot about it (one blog post doesn't mean they didn't forget). It brings me great joy knowing that several people working on this are now laid off, maybe now they will understand the risk of being an Early Access purchaser when they are turning tricks in the alley behind Arby's.


P.S. Anonymous person at Spicy Horse, stop writing blog posts. It just makes you look like a child when you blame reviewers for the game's negative press and financial failure. But thanks for plugging that new Spicy Horse game advertisement in your blog post! Real transparent of you guys.

reviewText: Terrible, even if this game were free I'd not buy it. I realize it's early access, but still, I've never played an ARPG since the origional Diablo that didn't allow key rebinding, Also, the default view when I go out on the first mission reminds me more of a 3rd person shooter game, and zooming with the Z key just made it worse (it brought the character even closer, not further as I hoped). I simply cannot move my character toward myself easily, as there is so little ground to click on with that view. I was expecting a view more like what I see in the village or the gameplay videos that made me decide to buy.\nI cannot reccomend this. If you have $5 to spare, wait for one of the two Torchlight titles to go on sale, or just eat the $5 bill and digest it, and then you'd get more from your money than I got from this game. I wish Steam gave refunds more easily.

reviewText: Very good RPG.  Artwork and music are an excellet match  for the theme.  No graphics problems on Xubuntu 14.04 with my GeForce GTX 750 Ti.  It does freeze about once an hour but that may be due to network problems with my satellite connection.  This requires terminating the process to close it.  Level progress is lost but gathered items are retained.  While the game is not finished (and won't be) and there are a few item bugs, it's an enjoyable RPG that doesn't require much investment if you just want to run around and kill things.  I do very well without much buying or crafting.

Early Access Review

I recommend it to fans of the genre who don't mind a more basic ARPG experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was participated in the beta testing for Akaneiro also, and since then it was improved a lot. I loved the art style, like most of Spicy Horse games it is more like an interactive art piece then a game. Similar to Alice Madness Returns.

One of it's great features is the implementing of eastern cultures, art and music into the game. Anyone who is interested in eastern cultures and mythology will find a lot of familiar elements in Akaneiro.

It has it's faults also, but I believe that compared to the ammount of people who were working on it it's a very nice little game. Challanging, but not too hard. it has a nice way of giving the players the choice what difficulty they want to play the game in, and it's not only makes the game harder, but the rewards higher also.

I say try it. It will either convince you to spend a few  evening as the hunter / huntress smashing Yokai, enjoying the story of the clan of hunters founded by Red or you will not like it that much.. I think because of the art it worth a try.
Also what is very much recommended is to get the artbook from Amazon or similar place (Art of Akaneiro). As mentioned earler Akaneiro is more like an interactive art, then a game in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Impressions:

If you like dungeon crawlers this worth the $5 sale price. It will inevitably be F2P, but the starter items you get with the purchase will hold you over for quite a while. The art style reminds me of Japanese paintings, the traditional sounding music fits the atmosphere perfectly, and the pacing has been good.

I was surprised to hear that the game has a lot in common with Bastion, but after seeing how they did the town I can see it.

At this point in early access the game is designed to start sending you back to the earlier areas at higher difficulties to allow you to grind xp and items. Enemy variety has been good for the early part of the game, but the maps appear to be static. I have always felt that randomized areas help give dungeon crawlers longevity so it'll be interesting to see what they do.

I suggest starting with the Fortitude character, currency is shared as well as the stash so if you decide to have multiple characters it's easy to pass stuff between them.

It also appears that you can summon an ally, even if offline, and they will get rewards for it. Very cool concept.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The combat seems to be okay, but the animations lack a little
For example, you're surrounded by wolves, and you just stand still hacking into the wolves, one by one
Atleast you have 3 abilities you can use from the start, but that normal attack on left mouse button is really a boring thing to watch
Especially when you have to kill a lot of enemies

So this is an ARPG, which is online. Why? There were no one in the game. I was all alone with the enemies and the NPCs
This also seems to be pay 2 win, since you can just buy more skills, or buy the upgrades to said skills

Overall a little boring. Might be a good time waster, if you have nothing else to do
Not worth 10€

reviewText:
Early Access Review

لعبة جيدة. لأنه فيه بعض أشياء عجبني في اللعبة مثل الرسم الي ذكرني كثير بلعبة Okami.
و طريقة المهام مختلفة عن بعضها البعض في مستويات مختلف و الي اقصدها ايزي نورمل و هارد, لأن هاي اللعبة تعطتني المهام بطريقة مختلفة و غير روتيني
و طبعا نظام الآر بي جي و ترقيات الشخصية فيه جيد كأي لعبة ثانية.

مع ذلك في اشياء خلتني اكره في اللعبة مثل ان النقاط (كارما) الي تعتبر كعملة في اللعبة, ما تحصلها كثير بالمهام الي تنفذها.
و طبعا لو تبغي هاي النقاط فلازم تشتري بمبلغ واقعي أي انه في نوع من مايكروترانزاكشن. و طبعا اسعاره مبالغة جداً
و كذلك فيه مشكلة تقنية في اللعبة, مثل ان اللعبة تغلق بنفسها فجأة و فيه فترات تحميل طويلة نسبيا و أحياناً.
و غير هذا  أن اللعبة تعتمد بشكل رئيسي على قتال عن القرب بالاسحلة, فهنا تأتي مشكلة عدم تنوع في الحركات كل الي عليك تسويه انك تضغط على وحش و اترك الشخصية تضرب الوحش بشكل تلقائي كألعاب mmo
بالأخير هاي ما تعتبر نسخة نهائية للعبة, نه مجرد نسخة تأهلني للوصول للنسخة النهائسة. يعني اللعبة في مرحلة التطوير

reviewText:
Early Access Review

American McGee worked on this game!

American McGee's Akaneiro: Demon Hunters with American McGee is a diablo-type game using an Asianfied Red Riding Hood storyline. Confused? American McGee isn't! The game is funnish when you're allowed to play, but it has strange facebook game timers and weird Free To Play mechanics that means once you've used up all your fun you can either wait around for more fun to unlock, or pay real people money.

American McGee is a jerk :/

reviewText: Regardless of how 'Akaneiro: Demon Hunters' may go down in ARPG history I will praise it for the artistic creativity that went into the look of this stylish linear Japanese lore inspired title. It instantly drew me in for the sensational surrealist world of characters, but turned me off by the fixed camera and highly linear single player only format.\n\nStill for 5 bucks I can't complain about price either. As for the rest? Apparently the developer left the publisher? So not sure about the future of this brand or its final product.

This is a free to play game (free to download on their website) the price on steam is for some extra currency and gear.
and there are optional micro transaction in the game.
It is a fun game but does not feel finished.
try the game for free on their website.
6/10

reviewText: It was disheartening to see nothing related to Red Riding hood, or any of the Grimms tales like I was promised.  I bought a game that is probably going to simply sit on my account.  It has features belying it to an MMO, but they're missing all three letters.  Massive - The game seems rather small, in what I can figure are up coming areas I've yet to be. Multiplayer - It certainly WANTED to be at some point, but it fell short in the fact that... you play by yourself.  Sure the character creation screen is limited due to them wanted to be online, and sure they have a number of purchasable features in game, but I came into this expecting a single-player action-adventure rpg.  What I got was some kind of purgatory between a Multiplayer game and a Single-player campaign.  Online - When you first get onto the game you're greeted with a Connecting to online" screen briefly.  This surprised me as nothing I had seen said anything about it being online.  You then go to your typical MMO character creation screen and
recommended: build your character.  Then you have to create a name
hoursPlayed: and anyone who's played an MMO before knows how arduous a task this is... I digress
voteText:
but after several different tries I got one that worked. Then I connected to the game.

And I was alone.

There was not a soul to be found
helpfulPercent: save the NPCs that eventually show up in town.  The little chat box at the bottom lay barren
votesHelpful: devoid of any purpose as there was nary a soul to talk to.\n\nThe game-play itself isn't bad
votesTotal: it plays a lot like guild wars.  The story seems to be there
votesFunny: but the awash of MMO features seem to render it bland and leaving of a bad taste in ones mouth.  Purgatory seems a good way to describe it.  Like a sort-of Limbo
commentsCount: never will you feel more isolated and alone than if you were to play this game."

reviewText:
This one had a good idea that was poorly executed, or even really finished for that matter.


After waiting an obscene amount of time, there was little progress made on the game. It also uses a pay-to-play model, but you can only get it if you buy the starter pack (note that you're not really buying the game, just the starter pack). I can only assume this is a way to drum up funds.

The game itself is, okay. Graphics are iffy, sounds are iffy, gameplay was, meh. Simple enough to figure out if you've played similar diablo-esque games, but there isn't really anything to make it stand out except for the fact that it's incomplete, and you have to pay for what should apparently be a free game. There really wasn't anything that held my attention for very long at the very least.

I'll check this one occasionally to see if they ever make any progress on it, but unless they do, this is one that is better off skipped over.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Worst. Game. In. My. Library. Ever.

I supported this game when Early Acces was pretty much a new thing and I figured, heck why not. I liked the art style and music...

Oh boy was i wrong.
Firstly nowhere was I openly informed on the store page, that this was to be a multiplatform, mainly mobile oriented game - complete with the restrictions and quirky controls that come with that.
Why would I want to support such a thing in the first place? Exactly i wouldn't.

I really wish Steam would enforce a policy, where publishers have to openly tag their offers as Mobile games be they ported or multiplatform.
I am a Windows PC custommer and Thats the platform I want to buy games for - not simplistic mobile ports.

On top of that this game is the prime example of a failed Early Access/Kickstarter/Whatever.
I understand that a Early Access purchase is not the promise to deliver a complete game later, but rather the promise to try - and many will obviously fail to do so.
Problem is, many tiny dev companies do a Early Acces without any realistic chance to ever successfully deliver, biting of far more thean they can chew.

This game is why I almost never buy Early Access anymore, unless I feel strongly compelled by a product or devteam.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It has potential, that much is certain. As it stands now though, the game feels like nothing more than a Free-to-Play MMO, quality wise. The stages follow the mobile method of finish one numbered area then move to the next which you will be scored in with gold and exp. Each single stage has three levels of difficulty which is unlocked when the previous difficulty is completed.

While this system works in mobile titles, it suffers here because it severly hurts the games ability to tell a story. Right now, before each stage, you are only given a small slideshow of pictures explaining the events leading to it. Very dissapointing considering the story" is actually what I looked forward to in this game. Red girl background and all.

All these said
date: the game is still in production and while I don't recommend it now
voteText: change my mind once the game is more complete."

reviewText: This game doesn't look good, doesn't feel good, and can lag the hell out. But it's fun. I don't even know why.\n\nThere's never any danger of dying (at least at low levels lol), and there's little actual skill involved in controlling your character. It plays more like a casual Diablo 3 than anything else. In the end, it's just a very very unfinished game. But play it -- it's free. You might find, like me, that it's actually very appealing.
